conclusion: Analyze forces on each section of the triangular conductor frame due to the magnetic field.
Magnetic force on a current-carrying wire is given by F = I * L * B * sin(theta).
Triangle is equilateral, all sides have the same length denoted as L.
Current flows directly from A to B.
Magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the triangle, so theta = 90 degrees and sin(90 degrees) = 1.
Force on section AB is given as F.
Current splits equally at point A and flows through AC and BC.
Angle between current in AC (or BC) and magnetic field is 90 degrees.
Current in each section AC and BC is half of the total current I.
Force on each section AC and BC is (1/2)I * L * B.
Forces on AC and BC are equal in magnitude but act in directions 120 degrees apart.
Resultant force of two vectors of equal magnitude F' at an angle of 120 degrees is F'.
Resultant force on AC and BC is (1/2)I * L * B.
Resultant force on AC and BC is (1/2)I * L * B.
Net force is F - (1/2)I * L * B.
Given F = I * L * B, net force is (1/2)I * L * B.
Magnitude of the resultant Ampere force on the three resistance wires is (1/2)F.
